variant.question: When the centre of gravity is at the forward limit, an aeroplane will be:

options.text: extremely stable and will require excessive elevator control to change pitch.
extremely stable and require small elevator control to change pitch.
extremely unstable and require excessive elevator control to change pitch.
extremely unstable and require small elevator control to change pitch.

variant.question: With regard to the CG limits of an aircraft, which of the following is true?

options.text: The aircraft operator’s CG limitations can be more restrictive than the manufacturer’s CG limitations.
It depends on the state of registry whether the manufacturer’s or the aircraft operator’s limitations on CG are more restrictive.
The manufacturer’s CG limitations can be more restrictive than the aircraft operator’s CG limitations.
The CG limitations of the operator always have to be the same as the manufacturer’s limitations.

variant.question: Which Section of the Aircraft Flight Manual describes the Centre of Gravity limitations?

options.text: Limitations
Emergency Procedures
Performance
Normal Procedures

variant.question: The effect of the centre of gravity (CG) being close to the forward limit is:

options.text: a decrease of the rate of climb capability.
a reduction in the specific fuel consumption.
a decrease in the induced drag.
an increase of the rate of climb capability.

variant.question: The effect of the centre of gravity (CG) being close to the forward limit is:

options.text: A reduced rate of climb capability.
An improved rate of climb capability.
Decreased induced drag.
Reduced specific fuel consumption.

variant.question: Explain the effect of a centre of gravity (CG) which is in front of the forward limit

options.text: Both the range and the absolute ceiling decrease.
Both the range and the absolute ceiling increase.
The range increases and the absolute ceiling decreases.
The range decreases and the absolute ceiling increases.

variant.question: With regard to the Centre of Gravity limits of an aircraft, which one of the following statements is true?

options.text: The aircraft operator’s CG limitations can be more restrictive than the manufacturer’s CG limitations.
The CG limitations of the operator always have to be the same as the manufacturer’s limitations.
It depends on the state of registry whether the manufacturer’s or the aircraft operator’s limitations on CG are more restrictive.
The manufacturer’s CG limitations can be more restrictive than the aircraft operator’s CG limitations.

variant.question: Basic Empty Mass (BEM):

options.text: Is usually determined by the aircraft manufacturer during weighing at the manufacturing plant and does not include any additional equipment.
Is the mass of an aeroplane as produced by the manufacturer including operating fluids, toilet and galley water plus all required equipment plus unusable fuel.
Is usually the mass of the basic aeroplane without any operating fluids.
Is the mass of an aeroplane including operating fluids, toilet and galley water and fuel.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 Determine the moment of Basic Empty Mass of the aeroplane.
Basic Empty Mass (BEM) is:

options.text: a component of Dry Operating Mass.
Dry Operating Mass minus fuel load.
the actual Take-off Mass, minus Traffic Load.
Dry Operating Mass minus Traffic Load.

variant.question: 5 600 USG is equivalent to:

options.text: 4663 Imp Gal
466 Imp Gal
4366 Imp Gal
633 Imp Gal

variant.question: The Basic Empty Mass (BEM) is the:

options.text: Operating mass minus the crew and fuel load.
Landing mass minus the traffic load.
Take-off mass minus the traffic load and the fuel load.
MZFM minus both traffic load and the fuel load.

variant.question: An aeroplane has a Basic Empty Mass of 1000 kg, located at station 92. The pilot's mass is 80 kg, located at station 100. The fuel mass is 120 kg, located at station 130. The length of the MAC is 60 inches, 0 % MAC is at station 80. What is the centre of gravity location of the loaded aeroplane in % MAC?

options.text: 20 % MAC

variant.question: The permissible CG range can be found in...

options.text: The Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM).
The checklist.
The minimum equipment list (MEL).
The aircraft technical log.

variant.question: The centre of gravity of an aircraft:

options.text: Can be allowed to move between defined limits.

Is in a fixed position and is unaffected by aircraft
loading.

May only be moved if permitted by the regulating
authority and endorsed in the aircraft's certificate of
airworthiness.

Must be maintained in a fixed position by careful
distribution of the load.

variant.question: The centre of gravity of an aircraft:

options.text: can be allowed to move between defined limits.
must be maintained in a fixed position by careful distribution of the load.
may only be moved if permitted by the regulating authority and endorsed in the aircraft's certificate of airworthiness.
is in a fixed position and is unaffected by aircraft loading.

variant.question:
The mass and balance information gives the following information: 
  
 Basic Empty Mass: 1 095 kg 
 CG at BEM: 1.98 m (25% MAC) 
 MAC: 2 m 
  
 In the mass and balance section of the flight manual the following information is given : 
  
 Pilot and front seat occupant: 80 kg each 
 front seats arm: 2.5 m 
 rear seats arm: 3.2 m 
 rear hold arm: 2.7 m 
 fuel tanks arm: 1.9 m 
  
 Fuel tanks contain 139 litres of 100LL with a density of 0.72. The rear seats are not occupied. Taxi fuel is negligable. 
 The position of the centre of gravity in percentage of Mean Aerodynamic Chord at take-off is:

options.text: 28% MAC
31% MAC
30% MAC
73% MAC

variant.question: The determination of the centre of gravity in relation to the Mean Aerodynamic Chord:

options.text: consists of defining the centre of gravity longitudinally in relation to the length of the Mean Aerodynamic Chord and the leading edge.
consists of defining the centre of gravity longitudinally in relation to the position of the aerodynamic convergence point.
consists of defining the centre of gravity longitudinally in relation to the position of the aerodynamic centre of pressure.
consists of defining the centre of gravity longitudinally in relation to the length of the Mean Aerodynamic Chord and the trailing edge.

variant.question: The position of the centre of gravity can always be determined by:

options.text: dividing the total moment by the Total Mass.
subtracting the Total Mass from the total moment.
subtracting the total moment from the Total Mass.
dividing the Total Mass by the total moment.

variant.question: The distance from the datum to the Centre of Gravity of a mass is known as:

options.text: The moment arm or balance arm.
The force.
The index.
The moment.

variant.question: Which of the following is unlikely to have any effect on the position of the centre of gravity on an aeroplane in flight ?

options.text: Changing the tailplane (horizontal stabiliser) incidence angle.
Lowering the landing gear.
Normal consumption of fuel for a swept wing aeroplane.
Movement of cabin attendants going about their normal duties.

variant.question: Which of the following is unlikely to have any effect on the position of the centre of gravity on an aeroplane in flight?

options.text: Changing the tailplane (horizontal stabiliser) incidence angle.
Normal consumption of fuel for a swept wing aeroplane.
Movement of cabin attendants going about their normal duties.
Lowering the landing gear.

variant.question: The Basic Empty Mass of an aircraft is recorded in..

options.text: the weighing schedule and is amended to take account of changes due to modifications of the aircraft.
the weighing schedule. If changes occur, due to modifications, the aircraft must be re-weighed always.
the loading manifest. It differs from Dry Operating Mass by the value of the traffic load.
the loading manifest. It differs from the Zero Fuel Mass by the value of the traffic load.

variant.question: What is the forward CG limit and what is the aft CG limit for an aircraft having a gross mass of 4 300 lbs?
Which section of the Aircraft Flight Manual describes the Centre of Gravity limits of the aircraft?

options.text: The aircraft limitations section.
None – they have to be individually computed for every flight.
The performance section.
The operational procedures section.

variant.question: Longitudinal CG location is normally expressed:

options.text: as a percentage of the MAC from its leading edge.
with respect to the centre of pressure.
with respect to the neutral point.
as a percentage of the MAC from its trailing edge.

variant.question: The Centre of Gravity of a body is that point

options.text: through which the sum of the forces of all masses of the body is considered to act.
which is used as the datum for computing moments.
where the sum of the moments from the external forces acting on the body is equal to zero.
where the sum of the external forces is equal to zero.

variant.question: Information about CG limits can be found...

options.text: in the Aircraft Flight Manual.
in the aircraft’s Certificate of Registration.
in the Aircraft Checklist.
on the Air Operator Certificate.

variant.question:
The centre of gravity of an aeroplane is at 25 % of the Mean Aerodynamic Chord
 This means that the centre of gravity of the aeroplane is situated at 25 % of the length of

options.text: the mean aerodynamic chord in relation to the leading edge.
the aeroplane in relation to the leading edge.
the mean aerodynamic chord in relation to the trailing edge.
the mean aerodynamic chord in relation to the datum.

variant.question: The centre of gravity of an aeroplane is at 25 % of the Mean Aerodynamic Chord. This means that the centre of gravity of the aeroplane is situated at 25 % of the length of:

options.text: the mean aerodynamic chord in relation to the leading edge.
the mean aerodynamic chord in relation to the trailing edge.
the aeroplane in relation to the leading edge.
the mean aerodynamic chord in relation to the datum.

variant.question: The centre of gravity of an aeroplane is at 25% of the Mean Aerodynamic Chord. This means that the centre of gravity of the aeroplane is situated at 25% of the length of:

options.text: the mean aerodynamic chord in relation to the leading edge.
the mean aerodynamic chord in relation to the datum.
the mean aerodynamic chord in relation to the trailing edge.
the aeroplane in relation to the leading edge.

variant.question: When must the centre of gravity (CG) be computed?

options.text: Prior to every flight.
At least every four years.
During every yearly inspection.
After every 400 hrs inspection.

variant.question: The centre of gravity is the

options.text: point where all the aircraft mass is considered to be concentrated.
neutral point along the longitudinal axis, in relation to a datum line.
focus along the longitudinal axis, in relation to a datum line.
centre of thrust along the longitudinal axis, in relation to a datum line.

variant.question: Refer to Annex. Using the loading manifest in the annex, determine the Basic Empty Mass of the aircraft.
The centre of gravity of an aircraft is that point through which the total mass of the aircraft is said to act. The weight acts in a direction

options.text: parallel to the gravity vector.
at right angles to the flight path.
always parallel to the aircraft's vertical axis.
governed by the distribution of the mass within the aircraft.

Refer to figure.

options.text: 116.2 in aft of datum and the moment is 362 876 in.lb.
156.7 in aft of datum and the moment is 489666 in.lb.
112.7 in aft of datum and the moment is 351 950 in.lb.
117.1 in aft of datum and the moment is 365 820 in.lb.

variant.question: The position of the centre of gravity can be determined by...

options.text: dividing the total moment by the sum of the masses.
multiplying the total mass by the sum of the moments.
multiplying the total moment by the sum of the masses.
dividing the total mass by the sum of the moments.

variant.question: Which one of the following equations is correct in order to calculate the Centre of Gravity?

options.text: Total moment divided by the sum of the masses.
Masses multiplied by the sum of the moments.
Total moment multiplied by the sum of the masses.
Masses divided by the sum of the moments.

variant.question: Along which axis is the centre of gravity location normally computed?

options.text: Longitudinal axis.
Vertical axis.
Horizontal axis.
Lateral axis.

variant.question: Where in the aircraft flight manual can the pilot find the CG limits?

options.text: In the aircraft limitations section.
In the performance section.
Nowhere – they have to be individually computed for every flight.
In the operational procedures section.

variant.question:
The basic empty mass of an aircraft is 1 000 kg, the empty mass CG is at station 92. The pilot mass at station 100 is 80 kg, the fuel mass at station 130 is 120 kg. The length of the MAC is 60 inches, with 0% MAC at station 80.
What is the centre of gravity position of the loaded aircraft in % MAC?

Refer to figure. 
 Where is the centre of gravity of the aeroplane in the diagram?

options.text: 26.57 cm forward of datum.
32.29 cm aft of datum.
26.57 cm aft of datum.
32.29 cm forward of datum.

variant.question: The reference about which centre of gravity moments are taken is the:

options.text: datum.
chord line.
centre of pressure.
centre of mass.

variant.question: The centre of gravity location of the aeroplane is normally computed along the:

options.text: longitudinal axis.
vertical axis.
lateral axis.
horizontal axis.

variant.question:
In calculations with respect to the position of the centre of gravity a reference is made to a datum
The datum is

options.text: a reference plane which is chosen by the aircraft manufacturer. Its position is given in the Aircraft Flight or Loading Manual.
an arbitrary reference chosen by the pilot which can be located anywhere on the aircraft.
calculated from the data derived from the weighing procedure carried out on the aircraft after any major modification.
calculated from the loading manifest.

variant.question: The centre of gravity is that (i) on an aircraft through which the total (ii) is considered to act vertically (iii).

options.text: i) point; ii) mass; iii) downwards
i) datum; ii) moment; iii) downwards
i) datum; ii) mass; iii) upwards
i) point; ii) moment; iii) upwards

variant.question: Which one of the following statements below best describes the Centre of Gravity (CG) of an aircraft?

options.text: The CG is the point at which the total weight is assumed to be concentrated.
The CG is the point at which the total weight is applied and acts in the longitudinal direction.
The CG is the point at which the sum of the values of the moments is NOT zero.
The CG is the point at which the sum of the balance arms is nil.

variant.question: Which one of the following statements below best describes the Centre of Gravity (CG) of an aircraft?

options.text: The CG is a theoretical point where all the mass is said to be concentrated.
The CG is a theoretical point stated in the Limitations section of the Aircraft Flight Manual.
The CG is a fixed point through which the three axes of the aircraft act.
The CG is a fixed point defined by the Operator and stated in the Operations Manual.

variant.question: The basic empty mass of an aeroplane is recorded in:

options.text: the weighing schedule and is amended to take account of changes due to modifications of the aeroplane.
the loading manifest. It differs from the zero fuel mass by the value of the "Traffic Load".
the loading manifest. It differs from dry operating mass by the value of the "Traffic Load".
the weighing schedule. If changes occur, due to modifications, the aeroplane must be re-weighed always.

options.text: Moments divided by the sum of the masses.
Masses multiplied by the sum of the moments.
Masses divided by the sum of the moments.
Moments multiplied by the sum of the masses.
